data.title: Ruby editor: typing #{ autocomplete annoying
data.body:
In general, all autocomplete functionality should obey this rule:

> Text automatically inserted in the current line is marked
> If the cursor is before a marked character and the marked character is entered, the cursor advances to the right one space and no further effect happens
> When leaving focus of the current line, all marking is lost

Following shows an example of a "helpful" autocomplete in Ruby becoming a pain:

![kismac2build2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/382183/6238329/2b1903da-b6c8-11e4-82d5-8731b6255929.gif)

data.title: investigate what happens when a socket is handed off to a child process
Uncaught Error: Encoding not recognized: 'utf-8-bom' (searched as: 'utf8bom')
data.body:
1. Try saving a UTF-8 file which has a BOM.

**Atom Version**: 0.179.0
**System**: Mac OS X 10.9.5
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: Encoding not recognized: 'utf-8-bom' (searched as: 'utf8bom')

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:782

Error: Encoding not recognized: 'utf-8-bom' (searched as: 'utf8bom')
  at Object.getCodec (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/6to5-core/node_modules/regenerator-6to5/node_modules/commoner/node_modules/iconv-lite/lib/index.js:104:23)
  at Object.encode (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/6to5-core/node_modules/regenerator-6to5/node_modules/commoner/node_modules/iconv-lite/lib/index.js:16:25)
  at File.module.exports.File.writeFileSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:241:49)
  at File.module.exports.File.writeFileWithPrivilegeEscalationSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:304:21)
  at File.module.exports.File.write (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:293:12)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.saveAs (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:970:17)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.save (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:958:19)
  at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.save (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/text-editor.js:620:26)
  at Pane.module.exports.Pane.saveItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:542:18)
  at Pane.module.exports.Pane.saveActiveItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:525:19)
  at Workspace.module.exports.Workspace.saveActivePaneItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace.js:679:35)
  at atom-workspace.atom.commands.add.core:save (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace-element.js:295:30)
  at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:243:29)
  at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:3:61
  at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:558:16)
  at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:396:22)
  at HTMLDocument.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.onKeydown (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:172:20)

```
### Commands

```
     -5:51.7 core:save (atom-text-editor.editor.is-focused)
     -5:14.0 core:copy (atom-notification.fatal.icon.icon-bug.native-key-bindings.has-detail.has-close.has-stack.remove)
     -5:11.5 core:paste (atom-text-editor.editor)
  3x -4:27.9 core:copy (atom-text-editor.editor)
     -0:03.6 find-and-replace:show (atom-text-editor.editor.is-focused)
     -0:02.0 editor:consolidate-selections (atom-text-editor.editor.mini)
     -0:02.0 core:cancel (atom-text-editor.editor.mini)
     -0:01.0 core:save (atom-text-editor.editor.is-focused)
```
### Config

``` json
{
  "core": {
    "themes": [
      "atom-dark-ui",
      "monokai"
    ],
    "useReactEditor": true
  },
  "editor": {
    "fontSize": 11,
    "showIndentGuide": true,
    "tabLength": 4,
    "invisibles": {}
  }
}
```
### Installed Packages

``` coffee
# User
docblockr, v0.5.8
editorconfig, v0.3.0
emmet, v2.3.3
git-tab-status, v1.5.3
linter, v0.11.1

minimap, v4.2.2
monokai, v0.12.0
regex-railroad-diagram, v0.6.3

# Dev
No dev packages
```

data.title: Allow building with node 12
data.body:
Since node 12 came out a week ago, [people have been trying to build with it](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5587) and they have been having issues.

```
[connexo@archgott atom]$ script/build 
Node: v0.12.0
npm: v2.5.1
Installing build modules...
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.
Installing apm...
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.

module.js:356
  Module._extensions[extension](this, filename);
                               ^
Error: /home/connexo/packages/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/git-utils/build/Release/git.node: undefined symbol: node_module_register
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:364:17)
    at require (module.js:380:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/connexo/packages/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/git-utils/lib/git.js:8:16)

    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
```

cc @franktopel

data.title: Moving the window of an unsaved tab should not prompt to save the document
data.body: Say you have two atom windows open. In one of the windows you have a tab with unsaved content. Right if you drag that tab from one atom window to the other, atom will prompt you to save the file. There's no reason for it to do this, the file's not being closed, nothing is being lost.

data.title: .gitignore hiding doesn't seem to honor negation
data.body:
Example `.gitignore`:

``` sh
/components/
!/components/foo/
!/components/bar/
```

Ideally, only `components/foo` and `components/bar` would be visible in tree view when "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths" is enabled

How to I open the feature shown here?

![d17b682c-b50a-11e4-8aa7-77f407583779](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/382183/6230790/688df1d6-b690-11e4-9848-205e14376db0.png)

Was expecting this the be listed at File -> Open Quickly..., and for the keyboard shortcut to be shown there.

data.title: Title bar is not appropriate for non-project files
data.body:
When a project is open (i.e. the file browser is open), if I open the LICENSE or other non-project file, then the title bar will show like:

> LICENSE -- /path/to/project

This is misleading because it implies that the `LICENSE` file is inside the /path/to/project when it is not. In fact... I have no idea where the hell LICENSE is. It would be better to have something else in the title bar. Recommendations are:
- `LICENSE`
- `Atom - LICENSE`
- `Atom - Version 0.179.0 - LICENSE`

Now, for example, when I open "Open your Config", the titlebar shows `config.cson -- /path/to/project`, I am unsure if this is a global config file or if the file is actually saved at /path/to/project/config.cson.

![screen shot 2015-02-17 at 10 23 46 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/382183/6230650/5197078e-b68f-11e4-9a82-a5b7b92aa02f.png)

![screen shot 2015-02-17 at 10 22 36 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/382183/6230652/546984be-b68f-11e4-808a-7d8747361fff.png)

data.title: Build fails on ARMv7 (Raspberry Pi / Debian)
data.body:
I'm not sure if this is the same issue as #3783, but as I get a different error message I thought a new issue was more appropriate.

I'm trying to get Atom running on a Raspberry Pi 2 Model B under Raspbian, using a normal user account with `sudo` only when root is required (i.e. I build everything as non-root). `uname -a` gives the following output:

`Linux raspberrypi 3.18.7-v7+ #755 SMP PREEMPT Thu Feb 12 17:20:48 GMT 2015 armv7l GNU/Linux`

I've installed on the dependencies as per the Linux build instructions, and I've compiled and installed Node.js v0.12.0 from source. Everything runs fine until I get to the following command:

`script/build`

This produces the following output on the console:

```
$ ./script/build 
Node: v0.12.0
npm: v1.4.28
Installing build modules...
child_process: customFds option is deprecated, use stdio instead.
gyp: name 'chromeos' is not defined while evaluating condition 'target_arch=="arm" and chromeos==1' in deps/breakpad/breakpad.gyp while loading dependencies of binding.gyp while trying to load binding.gyp
gyp ERR! configure error 
gyp ERR! stack Error: `gyp` failed with exit code: 1
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.onCpExit (/home/pi/dev/atom/build/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/configure.js:343:16)
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:110:17)
gyp ERR! stack     at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (child_process.js:1067:12)
gyp ERR! System Linux 3.18.7-v7+
gyp ERR! command "node" "/home/pi/dev/atom/build/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "rebuild"
gyp ERR! cwd /home/pi/dev/atom/build/node_modules/minidump
gyp ERR! node -v v0.12.0
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v1.0.1
gyp ERR! not ok 

npm ERR! minidump@0.8.0 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the minidump@0.8.0 install script.
npm ERR! This is most likely a problem with the minidump package,
npm ERR! not with npm itself.
npm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:
npm ERR!     node-gyp rebuild
npm ERR! You can get their info via:
npm ERR!     npm owner ls minidump
npm ERR! There is likely additional logging output above.
npm ERR! System Linux 3.18.7-v7+
npm ERR! command "node" "/home/pi/dev/atom/build/node_modules/.bin/npm" "--userconfig=/home/pi/dev/atom/.npmrc" "install" "--loglevel" "error"
npm ERR! cwd /home/pi/dev/atom/build
npm ERR! node -v v0.12.0
npm ERR! npm -v 1.4.28
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! not ok code 0
```

Is this a bug with Atom or the `minidump` package (as suggested in the error log)? I have very little experience with Node and this is the first time I've had to debug a problem related to it.

data.title: Uncaught Error: Atom can only handle files < 2MB for now.
data.body:
I just try to open my xml file that is about 2.5Mb but atom give me an error like:

Uncaught Error: Atom can only handle files < 2MB for now.

**Atom Version**: 0.158.0
**System**: linux 3.11.0-12-generic
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Steps To Reproduce
1. ...
2. ...
### Stack Trace

```
At /usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/project.js:461

Error: Atom can only handle files < 2MB for now.
  at Project.module.exports.Project.buildBuffer (/usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/project.js:461:15)

Hi there,

I would love it if I could sort the keybindings by source type.

data.title: Rename 6to5 to Babel
data.body: 6to5 has been renamed to Babel, more information [here](http://babeljs.io/blog/2015/02/15/not-born-to-die/).

data.title: XCompose not working for higher-level shifts
data.body:
When issuing an XCompose sequence that involves a key on a shift level higher than 2, Atom ignores the input.

E. g., my parentheses are on level 3 of my keyboard layout. Now, when issuing `Compose+(+(`, which normally produces the character `⦅`, Atom produces no output.

Below is the xev output for this sequence. Generally, all XCompose sequences using keys that are not on levels 1 or 2 are ignored. The other sequences (base level and level-1 shift) do work, however.

```
KeyPress event, serial 28, synthetic NO, window 0x3000001,
    root 0x2bb, subw 0x0, time 5189912, (405,539), root:(1366,540),
    state 0x0, keycode 66 (keysym 0xff7e, Mode_switch), same_screen YES,
    XLookupString gives 0 bytes: 
    XmbLookupString gives 0 bytes: 
    XFilterEvent returns: False

    root 0x2bb, subw 0x0, time 5189968, (405,539), root:(1366,540),

data.title: GitHub Flavored Markdown
data.body:
The markdown preview window doesn’t render some GitHub Flavoured Markdown properly.

Roses are red
Violets are blue

In Atom, these lines don’t break, which is correct Markdown behaviour but not correct GitHub Flavoured Markdown behaviour.

Furthermore, references are not being auto-linked.
- SHA: a5c3785ed8d6a35868bc169f07e40e889087fd2e
- User@SHA: jlord@a5c3785ed8d6a35868bc169f07e40e889087fd2e
- User/Repository@SHA: jlord/sheetsee.js@a5c3785ed8d6a35868bc169f07e40e889087fd2e
- #Num: #26
- GH-Num: GH-26
- User#Num: jlord#26
- User/Repository#Num: jlord/sheetsee.js#26

data.title: Use double colons for "before" and "after" pseudo-elements
data.body: In CSS3, single colon for pseudo-elements is deprecated.

data.title: Atom not cleaning up some temp files
data.body: I am clearing out my temp files on Windows and I noticed that there are a whole bunch of folders prefixed with "npm" and "ssh" that I believe are from Atom (Node Package Manager?). Once a package is installed, Atom should probably clean out these temporary files. Between Atom and Squirrel, I've cleaned out nearly 3gb of temporary files from the past three weeks.

data.title: Docs task unclear
data.body: I would like to create a [Dash](http://kapeli.com/dash) docset for Atom, but I can't seem to build the docs. I tried running `grunt docs` inside the `build` directory, but it can't find `markdown:guides` task. Running only `grunt build-docs` does generate something, `docs/output/api.json`, but I don't know where to go from here.

data.title: How to enable retina device for osx travis-ci?
data.body:
My package need to dectct the `window.devicePixelRatio` attribute。
And the `window.devicePixelRatio` is always `1`.
How to change it in Travis-Ci?

data.title: Indent soft wrap
data.body:
This fixes #1125.

It still needs a lot of refactoring (and some test cases too), but I just wanted to evaluate the approach that me and @nathansobo agreed on the aforementioned issue. To recap, the following is a brief explanation of how the solution works.

When lines with an indentation are soft wrapped, they are prepended with a phantom token which is as long as the indentation of the original line. This token is not selectable, nor reachable by the cursor. I had to change how `DisplayBuffer#clipScreenPosition` worked, since I could not treat the phantom token as an hard tab. I'd like to remark that this is still experimental code, but based on my tests I can confirm it works pretty well.

~~There's a subtle bug, though, which needs to be addressed and which I'll be looking at soon after creating this pull request. When a line is indented but no space is present, Atom freezes: I am quite sure this is due to how soft wrapping works on lines without spaces (namely, lines without words). I am quite sure this can be fixed easily, it just needs some more attention (and a better knowledge of the codebase).~~

Thanks everyone in advance for the support!

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: First start: 4 atom apps running: --eval require('...source-maps')
